posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"There are lots of powerful things you can do with the Ghost editor

If you've gotten pretty comfortable with [all the basics](/the-editor/) of writing in Ghost, then you may enjoy some more advanced tips about the types of things you can do with Markdown!

As with the last post about the editor, you'll want to be actually editing this post as you read it so that you can see all the Markdown code we're using.


## Special formatting

As well as bold and italics, you can also use some other special formatting in Markdown when the need arises, for example:

+ ~~strike through~~
+ ==highlight==
+ \*escaped characters\*


## Writing code blocks

There are two types of code elements which can be inserted in Markdown, the first is inline, and the other is block. Inline code is formatted by wrapping any word or words in back-ticks, `like this`. Larger snippets of code can be displayed across multiple lines using triple back ticks:

```
.my-link {
    text-decoration: underline;
}
```

If you want to get really fancy, you can even add syntax highlighting using [Prism.js](http://prismjs.com/).


## Full bleed images

One neat trick which you can use in Markdown to distinguish between different types of images is to add a `#hash` value to the end of the source URL, and then target images containing the hash with special styling. For example:

![walking](https://casper.ghost.org/v1.0.0/images/walking.jpg#full)

which is styled with...

```
img[src$="#full"] {
    max-width: 100vw;
}
```

This creates full-bleed images in the Casper theme, which stretch beyond their usual boundaries right up to the edge of the window. Every theme handles these types of things slightly differently, but it's a great trick to play with if you want to have a variety of image sizes and styles.


## Reference lists

**The quick brown [fox][1], jumped over the lazy [dog][2].**

[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox "Wikipedia: Fox"
[2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dog "Wikipedia: Dog"

Another way to insert links in markdown is using reference lists. You might want to use this style of linking to cite reference material in a Wikipedia-style. All of the links are listed at the end of the document, so you can maintain full separation between content and its source or reference.


## Creating footnotes

The quick brown fox[^1] jumped over the lazy dog[^2].

[^1]: Foxes are red
[^2]: Dogs are usually not red

Footnotes are a great way to add additional contextual details when appropriate. Ghost will automatically add footnote content to the very end of your post.


## Full HTML

Perhaps the best part of Markdown is that you're never limited to just Markdown. You can write HTML directly in the Ghost editor and it will just work as HTML usually does. No limits! Here's a standard YouTube embed code as an example:

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Cniqsc9QfDo?rel=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}

posts.title: Organising your content with tags
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Ghost has a single, powerful organisational taxonomy, called tags.

It doesn't matter whether you want to call them categories, tags, boxes, or anything else. You can think of Ghost tags a lot like Gmail labels. By tagging posts with one or more keyword, you can organise articles into buckets of related content.


## Basic tagging

When you write a post, you can assign tags to help differentiate between categories of content. For example, you might tag some posts with `News` and other posts with `Cycling`, which would create two distinct categories of content listed on `/tag/news/` and `/tag/cycling/`, respectively.

If you tag a post with both `News` *and* `Cycling` - then it appears in both sections.

Tag archives are like dedicated home-pages for each category of content that you have. They have their own pages, their own RSS feeds, and can support their own cover images and meta data.


## The primary tag

Inside the Ghost editor, you can drag and drop tags into a specific order. The first tag in the list is always given the most importance, and some themes will only display the primary tag (the first tag in the list) by default. So you can add the most important tag which you want to show up in your theme, but also add a bunch of related tags which are less important.

==**News**, Cycling, Bart Stevens, Extreme Sports==

In this example, **News** is the primary tag which will be displayed by the theme, but the post will also still receive all the other tags, and show up in their respective archives.


## Private tags

Sometimes you may want to assign a post a specific tag, but you don't necessarily want that tag appearing in the theme or creating an archive page. In Ghost, hashtags are private and can be used for special styling.

For example, if you sometimes publish posts with video content - you might want your theme to adapt and get rid of the sidebar for these posts, to give more space for an embedded video to fill the screen. In this case, you could use private tags to tell your theme what to do.

==**News**, Cycling, #video==

Here, the theme would assign the post publicly displayed tags of `News`, and `Cycling` - but it would also keep a private record of the post being tagged with `#video`.

In your theme, you could then look for private tags conditionally and give them special formatting:

```
{{#post}}
    {{#has tag="#video"}}
        ...markup for a nice big video post layout...
    {{else}}
        ...regular markup for a post...
    {{/has}}
{{/post}}
```

You can find documentation for theme development techniques like this and many more over on Ghost's extensive [theme documentation](https://themes.ghost.org/)."}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Ghost has a single, powerful organisational taxonomy, called tags.

It doesn't matter whether you want to call them categories, tags, boxes, or anything else. You can think of Ghost tags a lot like Gmail labels. By tagging posts with one or more keyword, you can organise articles into buckets of related content.

Basic tagging

When you write a post, you can assign tags to help differentiate between categories of content. For example, you might tag some posts with News and other posts with Cycling, which would create two distinct categories of content listed on /tag/news/ and /tag/cycling/, respectively.

If you tag a post with both News and Cycling - then it appears in both sections.

Tag archives are like dedicated home-pages for each category of content that you have. They have their own pages, their own RSS feeds, and can support their own cover images and meta data.

The primary tag

Inside the Ghost editor, you can drag and drop tags into a specific order. The first tag in the list is always given the most importance, and some themes will only display the primary tag (the first tag in the list) by default. So you can add the most important tag which you want to show up in your theme, but also add a bunch of related tags which are less important.

News, Cycling, Bart Stevens, Extreme Sports

In this example, News is the primary tag which will be displayed by the theme, but the post will also still receive all the other tags, and show up in their respective archives.

Private tags

Sometimes you may want to assign a post a specific tag, but you don't necessarily want that tag appearing in the theme or creating an archive page. In Ghost, hashtags are private and can be used for special styling.

For example, if you sometimes publish posts with video content - you might want your theme to adapt and get rid of the sidebar for these posts, to give more space for an embedded video to fill the screen. In this case, you could use private tags to tell your theme what to do.

News, Cycling, #video

Here, the theme would assign the post publicly displayed tags of News, and Cycling - but it would also keep a private record of the post being tagged with #video.

In your theme, you could then look for private tags conditionally and give them special formatting:

{{#post}}
    {{#has tag="#video"}}
        ...markup for a nice big video post layout...
    {{else}}
        ...regular markup for a post...
    {{/has}}
{{/post}}

You can find documentation for theme development techniques like this and many more over on Ghost's extensive theme documentation.

Ghost has a single, powerful organisational taxonomy, called tags.

It doesn't matter whether you want to call them categories, tags, boxes, or
anything else. You can think of Ghost tags a lot like Gmail labels. By tagging
posts with one or more keyword, you can organise articles into buckets of
related content.

Basic tagging
When you write a post, you can assign tags to help differentiate between
categories of content. For example, you might tag some posts with News  and
other posts with Cycling, which would create two distinct categories of content
listed on /tag/news/  and /tag/cycling/, respectively.

If you tag a post with both News  and  Cycling  - then it appears in both
sections.

Tag archives are like dedicated home-pages for each category of content that you
have. They have their own pages, their own RSS feeds, and can support their own
cover images and meta data.

The primary tag
Inside the Ghost editor, you can drag and drop tags into a specific order. The
first tag in the list is always given the most importance, and some themes will
only display the primary tag (the first tag in the list) by default. So you can
add the most important tag which you want to show up in your theme, but also add
a bunch of related tags which are less important.

News, Cycling, Bart Stevens, Extreme Sports

In this example, News  is the primary tag which will be displayed by the theme,
but the post will also still receive all the other tags, and show up in their
respective archives.

Private tags
Sometimes you may want to assign a post a specific tag, but you don't
necessarily want that tag appearing in the theme or creating an archive page. In
Ghost, hashtags are private and can be used for special styling.

For example, if you sometimes publish posts with video content - you might want
your theme to adapt and get rid of the sidebar for these posts, to give more
space for an embedded video to fill the screen. In this case, you could use
private tags to tell your theme what to do.

News, Cycling, #video

Here, the theme would assign the post publicly displayed tags of News, and 
Cycling  - but it would also keep a private record of the post being tagged with
 #video.

In your theme, you could then look for private tags conditionally and give them
special formatting:

{{#post}}
    {{#has tag="#video"}}
        ...markup for a nice big video post layout...
    {{else}}
        ...regular markup for a post...
    {{/has}}
{{/post}}


You can find documentation for theme development techniques like this and many
more over on Ghost's extensive theme documentation [https://themes.ghost.org/].

{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Ghost uses a language called **Markdown** to format text.

When you go to edit a post and see special characters and colours intertwined between the words, those are Markdown shortcuts which tell Ghost what to do with the words in your document. The biggest benefit of Markdown is that you can quickly apply formatting as you type, without needing to pause.

At the bottom of the editor, you'll find a toolbar with basic formatting options to help you get started as easily as possible. You'll also notice that there's a **?** icon, which contains more advanced shortcuts.

For now, though, let's run you through some of the basics. You'll want to make sure you're editing this post in order to see all the Markdown we've used.


## Formatting text

The most common shortcuts are of course, **bold** text, _italic_ text, and [hyperlinks](https://example.com). These generally make up the bulk of any document. You can type the characters out, but you can also use keyboard shortcuts.

* `CMD/Ctrl + B` for Bold
* `CMD/Ctrl + I` for Italic
* `CMD/Ctrl + K` for a Link
* `CMD/Ctrl + H` for a Heading (Press multiple times for h2/h3/h4/etc)

With just a couple of extra characters here and there, you're well on your way to creating a beautifully formatted story.


## Inserting images

Images in Markdown look just the same as links, except they're prefixed with an exclamation mark, like this:

`![Image description](/path/to/image.jpg)`

![Computer](https://casper.ghost.org/v1.0.0/images/computer.jpg)

Most Markdown editors don't make you type this out, though. In Ghost you can click on the image icon in the toolbar at the bottom of the editor, or you can just click and drag an image from your desktop directly into the editor. Both will upload the image for you and generate the appropriate Markdown.

_**Important Note:** Ghost does not currently have automatic image resizing, so it's always a good idea to make sure your images aren't gigantic files **before** uploading them to Ghost._


## Making lists

Lists in HTML are a formatting nightmare, but in Markdown they become an absolute breeze with just a couple of characters and a bit of smart automation. For numbered lists, just write out the numbers. For bullet lists, just use `*` or `-` or `+`. Like this:

1. Crack the eggs over a bowl
2. Whisk them together
3. Make an omelette

or

- Remember to buy milk
- Feed the cat
- Come up with idea for next story


## Adding quotes

When you want to pull out a particularly good excerpt in the middle of a piece, you can use `>` at the beginning of a paragraph to turn it into a Blockquote. You might've seen this formatting before in email clients.

> A well placed quote guides a reader through a story, helping them to understand the most important points being made

All themes handles blockquotes slightly differently. Sometimes they'll look better kept shorter, while other times you can quote fairly hefty amounts of text and get away with it. Generally, the safest option is to use blockquotes sparingly.


## Dividing things up

If you're writing a piece in parts and you just feel like you need to divide a couple of sections distinctly from each other, a horizontal rule might be just what you need. Dropping `---` on a new line will create a sleek divider, anywhere you want it.

---

This should get you going with the vast majority of what you need to do in the editor, but if you're still curious about more advanced tips then check out the [Advanced Markdown Guide](/advanced-markdown/) - or if you'd rather learn about how Ghost taxononomies work, we've got a overview of [how to use Ghost tags](/using-tags/)."}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Ghost uses a language called Markdown to format text.

When you go to edit a post and see special characters and colours intertwined between the words, those are Markdown shortcuts which tell Ghost what to do with the words in your document. The biggest benefit of Markdown is that you can quickly apply formatting as you type, without needing to pause.

At the bottom of the editor, you'll find a toolbar with basic formatting options to help you get started as easily as possible. You'll also notice that there's a ? icon, which contains more advanced shortcuts.

For now, though, let's run you through some of the basics. You'll want to make sure you're editing this post in order to see all the Markdown we've used.

Formatting text

The most common shortcuts are of course, bold text, italic text, and hyperlinks. These generally make up the bulk of any document. You can type the characters out, but you can also use keyboard shortcuts.

  • CMD/Ctrl + B for Bold
  • CMD/Ctrl + I for Italic
  • CMD/Ctrl + K for a Link
  • CMD/Ctrl + H for a Heading (Press multiple times for h2/h3/h4/etc)

With just a couple of extra characters here and there, you're well on your way to creating a beautifully formatted story.

Inserting images

Images in Markdown look just the same as links, except they're prefixed with an exclamation mark, like this:

![Image description](/path/to/image.jpg)

Most Markdown editors don't make you type this out, though. In Ghost you can click on the image icon in the toolbar at the bottom of the editor, or you can just click and drag an image from your desktop directly into the editor. Both will upload the image for you and generate the appropriate Markdown.

Important Note: Ghost does not currently have automatic image resizing, so it's always a good idea to make sure your images aren't gigantic files before uploading them to Ghost.

Making lists

Lists in HTML are a formatting nightmare, but in Markdown they become an absolute breeze with just a couple of characters and a bit of smart automation. For numbered lists, just write out the numbers. For bullet lists, just use * or - or +. Like this:

  1. Crack the eggs over a bowl
  2. Whisk them together
  3. Make an omelette

or

  • Remember to buy milk
  • Feed the cat
  • Come up with idea for next story

Adding quotes

When you want to pull out a particularly good excerpt in the middle of a piece, you can use > at the beginning of a paragraph to turn it into a Blockquote. You might've seen this formatting before in email clients.

A well placed quote guides a reader through a story, helping them to understand the most important points being made

All themes handles blockquotes slightly differently. Sometimes they'll look better kept shorter, while other times you can quote fairly hefty amounts of text and get away with it. Generally, the safest option is to use blockquotes sparingly.

Dividing things up

If you're writing a piece in parts and you just feel like you need to divide a couple of sections distinctly from each other, a horizontal rule might be just what you need. Dropping --- on a new line will create a sleek divider, anywhere you want it.

This should get you going with the vast majority of what you need to do in the editor, but if you're still curious about more advanced tips then check out the Advanced Markdown Guide - or if you'd rather learn about how Ghost taxononomies work, we've got a overview of how to use Ghost tags.

document. You can type the characters out, but you can also use keyboard
shortcuts.

 * CMD/Ctrl + I  for Italic

to creating a beautifully formatted story.

For numbered lists, just write out the numbers. For bullet lists, just use *  or

 2. Whisk them together
 3. Make an omelette

or

Adding quotes
When you want to pull out a particularly good excerpt in the middle of a piece,

A well placed quote guides a reader through a story, helping them to understand

how Ghost taxononomies work, we've got a overview of how to use Ghost tags
[/using-tags/].

We might use something like this when the visuals on a graphics are too detailed to render through our traditional embed. The creator of the demo wanted to show: * Using QGIS to prepare your shapefile data * Creating layered Mapbox tilesets * Pulling it together into an interactive web map * Dynamic color changes based on interaction with the data ## Flourish Studio
A new tool was published 2/1 by a leading digital storytelling firm with the purpose of making data visualization simpler and more effective. The below is an embedded examples created after a 15 minute demo of the product. [https://flourish.studio/](https://flourish.studio/)

posts.html:
MapBoxGL

Here is a really interesting demo that uses MapBox GL to render complex map visualization of Edmonton property values. We might use something like this when the visuals on a graphics are too detailed to render through our traditional embed. The creator of the demo wanted to show:

  • Using QGIS to prepare your shapefile data
  • Creating layered Mapbox tilesets
  • Pulling it together into an interactive web map
  • Dynamic color changes based on interaction with the data

Flourish Studio

A new tool was published 2/1 by a leading digital storytelling firm with the purpose of making data visualization simpler and more effective. The below is an embedded examples created after a 15 minute demo of the product. https://flourish.studio/

posts.title: Welcome to Ghost
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Ghost uses a language called **Markdown** to format text.

When you go to edit a post and see special characters and colours intertwined between the words, those are Markdown shortcuts which tell Ghost what to do with the words in your document. The biggest benefit of Markdown is that you can quickly apply formatting as you type, without needing to pause.

At the bottom of the editor, you'll find a toolbar with basic formatting options to help you get started as easily as possible. You'll also notice that there's a **?** icon, which contains more advanced shortcuts.

For now, though, let's run you through some of the basics. You'll want to make sure you're editing this post in order to see all the Markdown we've used.


## Formatting text

The most common shortcuts are of course, **bold** text, _italic_ text, and [hyperlinks](https://example.com). These generally make up the bulk of any document. You can type the characters out, but you can also use keyboard shortcuts.

* `CMD/Ctrl + B` for Bold
* `CMD/Ctrl + I` for Italic
* `CMD/Ctrl + K` for a Link
* `CMD/Ctrl + H` for a Heading (Press multiple times for h2/h3/h4/etc)

With just a couple of extra characters here and there, you're well on your way to creating a beautifully formatted story.


## Inserting images

Images in Markdown look just the same as links, except they're prefixed with an exclamation mark, like this:

`![Image description](/path/to/image.jpg)`

![Computer](https://casper.ghost.org/v1.0.0/images/computer.jpg)

Most Markdown editors don't make you type this out, though. In Ghost you can click on the image icon in the toolbar at the bottom of the editor, or you can just click and drag an image from your desktop directly into the editor. Both will upload the image for you and generate the appropriate Markdown.

_**Important Note:** Ghost does not currently have automatic image resizing, so it's always a good idea to make sure your images aren't gigantic files **before** uploading them to Ghost._


## Making lists

Lists in HTML are a formatting nightmare, but in Markdown they become an absolute breeze with just a couple of characters and a bit of smart automation. For numbered lists, just write out the numbers. For bullet lists, just use `*` or `-` or `+`. Like this:

1. Crack the eggs over a bowl
2. Whisk them together
3. Make an omelette

or

- Remember to buy milk
- Feed the cat
- Come up with idea for next story


## Adding quotes

When you want to pull out a particularly good excerpt in the middle of a piece, you can use `>` at the beginning of a paragraph to turn it into a Blockquote. You might've seen this formatting before in email clients.

> A well placed quote guides a reader through a story, helping them to understand the most important points being made

All themes handles blockquotes slightly differently. Sometimes they'll look better kept shorter, while other times you can quote fairly hefty amounts of text and get away with it. Generally, the safest option is to use blockquotes sparingly.


## Dividing things up

If you're writing a piece in parts and you just feel like you need to divide a couple of sections distinctly from each other, a horizontal rule might be just what you need. Dropping `---` on a new line will create a sleek divider, anywhere you want it.

---

This should get you going with the vast majority of what you need to do in the editor, but if you're still curious about more advanced tips then check out the [Advanced Markdown Guide](/advanced-markdown/) - or if you'd rather learn about how Ghost taxononomies work, we've got a overview of [how to use Ghost tags](/using-tags/).

There are lots of powerful things you can do with the Ghost editor

If you've gotten pretty comfortable with [all the basics](/the-editor/) of writing in Ghost, then you may enjoy some more advanced tips about the types of things you can do with Markdown!

As with the last post about the editor, you'll want to be actually editing this post as you read it so that you can see all the Markdown code we're using.


## Special formatting

As well as bold and italics, you can also use some other special formatting in Markdown when the need arises, for example:

+ ~~strike through~~
+ ==highlight==
+ \*escaped characters\*


## Writing code blocks

There are two types of code elements which can be inserted in Markdown, the first is inline, and the other is block. Inline code is formatted by wrapping any word or words in back-ticks, `like this`. Larger snippets of code can be displayed across multiple lines using triple back ticks:

```
.my-link {
    text-decoration: underline;
}
```

If you want to get really fancy, you can even add syntax highlighting using [Prism.js](http://prismjs.com/).


## Full bleed images

One neat trick which you can use in Markdown to distinguish between different types of images is to add a `#hash` value to the end of the source URL, and then target images containing the hash with special styling. For example:

![walking](https://casper.ghost.org/v1.0.0/images/walking.jpg#full)

which is styled with...

```
img[src$="#full"] {
    max-width: 100vw;
}
```

This creates full-bleed images in the Casper theme, which stretch beyond their usual boundaries right up to the edge of the window. Every theme handles these types of things slightly differently, but it's a great trick to play with if you want to have a variety of image sizes and styles.


## Reference lists

**The quick brown [fox][1], jumped over the lazy [dog][2].**

[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox "Wikipedia: Fox"
[2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dog "Wikipedia: Dog"

Another way to insert links in markdown is using reference lists. You might want to use this style of linking to cite reference material in a Wikipedia-style. All of the links are listed at the end of the document, so you can maintain full separation between content and its source or reference.


## Creating footnotes

The quick brown fox[^1] jumped over the lazy dog[^2].

[^1]: Foxes are red
[^2]: Dogs are usually not red

Footnotes are a great way to add additional contextual details when appropriate. Ghost will automatically add footnote content to the very end of your post.


## Full HTML

Perhaps the best part of Markdown is that you're never limited to just Markdown. You can write HTML directly in the Ghost editor and it will just work as HTML usually does. No limits! Here's a standard YouTube embed code as an example:

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Cniqsc9QfDo?rel=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}

  1. Crack the eggs over a bowl
  2. Whisk them together
  3. Make an omelette

or

  • Remember to buy milk
  • Feed the cat
  • Come up with idea for next story

Adding quotes

When you want to pull out a particularly good excerpt in the middle of a piece, you can use > at the beginning of a paragraph to turn it into a Blockquote. You might've seen this formatting before in email clients.

A well placed quote guides a reader through a story, helping them to understand the most important points being made

All themes handles blockquotes slightly differently. Sometimes they'll look better kept shorter, while other times you can quote fairly hefty amounts of text and get away with it. Generally, the safest option is to use blockquotes sparingly.

If you're writing a piece in parts and you just feel like you need to divide a couple of sections distinctly from each other, a horizontal rule might be just what you need. Dropping --- on a new line will create a sleek divider, anywhere you want it.

  • strike through
  • highlight
  • *escaped characters*

Writing code blocks

There are two types of code elements which can be inserted in Markdown, the first is inline, and the other is block. Inline code is formatted by wrapping any word or words in back-ticks, like this. Larger snippets of code can be displayed across multiple lines using triple back ticks:

    text-decoration: underline;
}

If you want to get really fancy, you can even add syntax highlighting using Prism.js.

One neat trick which you can use in Markdown to distinguish between different types of images is to add a #hash value to the end of the source URL, and then target images containing the hash with special styling. For example:

which is styled with...

img[src$="#full"] {
    max-width: 100vw;

This creates full-bleed images in the Casper theme, which stretch beyond their usual boundaries right up to the edge of the window. Every theme handles these types of things slightly differently, but it's a great trick to play with if you want to have a variety of image sizes and styles.

posts.html:
Congrats, you have made it into the Mission Log and are ready to create your first project and project entry.


Photo by SpaceX / Unsplash

First, we will want to create a Tag, which will be used for all entries related to the project. You can browse a page filled with entries connected to a Tag, so by using this organization we create convenient wrap-up pages automatically.

For example, this is a Tutorials update. You can view all tutorial updates here: http://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/tag/tutorials/.

Follow the hyperlink to find Tutorial 2.

This post is about making more with less. You should see this page on the backend [here.](https://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/ghost/#/editor/5a86f578d6a55f0022e03337)
# Use # to create headers. H1 is #.

posts.title: Insights Admin tutorial
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Three tasks often come up with the portal:
1. Posting new content. 
2. Adding/editing users. 
3. and rotating the tiles. 

### Upload new premium content 

The time has come to publish new premium content. All public content gets syndicated into Insights, but we are responsible for uploading 50 State, Analytics, Ask Manatt, Manatt Insights, and Regulatory and Guidance Summaries. This process is initiated by a successful Content Submission Form.
1. Content submission form contains all fields needed to post.
2. Open the [Admin](https://www.manatt.com/Admin/CMSAdministration.aspx?nodeid=1272987&returnviewmode=editlive#) and navigate to the Premium Insights Content folder with the correct type.
3. With the folder selected, press the + button in top left of Admin. 
![6c8cf09ecfaf44ce9d88898da603f187](/content/images/2018/04/6c8cf09ecfaf44ce9d88898da603f187.gif)
4. Input all text to the corresponding field, Check the Health Insights Content box, and complete the additional fields like Key Topics and States. Place in the Content Notification description, but do not check Send Notification yet.
5. Save progress, attach any documents, save progress, and then generate a preview link.
6. If preview looks correct, send to content lead for approval.
7. Once approved, check Send Notification if there is one, then publish. 
8. Send published link to the content lead.
<iframe width="630" height="355" src="https://www.useloom.com/embed/e789525bec1d465392e79bc13dd88323" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

*Avoid the mistake I make at the end, when I publish the content before selecting Send Notification.*

### Create new users
User creation is a pretty straightforward process.
1. Log in to the Admin and access Configuration > [Users](https://www.manatt.com/Admin/cmsadministration.aspx#9823f848-bb15-4b21-8769-dc80b7adcd4c) 
2. Access the Worksite portal login (currently restricted to Alex + Catherine), and add users Organization, Full Name, and Email. 
3. If more passwords are needed, generate from [Random](https://www.random.org/strings/) using 6 characters per string, Numeric Digits and lowercase letters.
4. In the Admin, use email for username and email, enter full name, and the password in line from the login sheet. Change privilege level to None and Save.
5.  Add first and last name fields, save.
6.  Go to User Roles, add Health Insights User, save.
7.  Test login credentials before sending to user.

<iframe width="630" height="355" src="https://www.useloom.com/embed/66891563ee9745daa9124213f981ab2b" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

### Rotating the tiles
The steps to rotate tiles on a landing page are simple.
1. Open the landing page as a reference in one.
2. Open the landing page in admin backend.
    * Options are Home, Key Topics, or Premium Content.
3. Open a tab with `data:text/html, <html contenteditable>` to store text
4. Starting with the tile where rotation starts, copy all field content over to the text storage tab. This includes Title, Link, and for public content, social links.
5. When all text is copied, paste in the new Title, Link, confirm correct Content Type, and upload the image for the new tile. 
6. Copy the replaced tile content into the next position, and repeat until all tiles are rotated.
<iframe width="630" height="355" src="https://www.useloom.com/embed/07fd935899ca418399b7381a38f07879" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

### Bonus training - SF Export 
<iframe width="630" height="355" src="https://www.useloom.com/embed/6ac66ead20cd4d0cbc410c2878994a2b" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}

  5. Save progress, attach any documents, save progress, and then generate a preview link.
  6. If preview looks correct, send to content lead for approval.
  7. Once approved, check Send Notification if there is one, then publish.
  8. Send published link to the content lead.

Avoid the mistake I make at the end, when I publish the content before selecting Send Notification.

Create new users

  1. Log in to the Admin and access Configuration > Users
  2. Access the Worksite portal login (currently restricted to Alex + Catherine), and add users Organization, Full Name, and Email.
  3. If more passwords are needed, generate from Random using 6 characters per string, Numeric Digits and lowercase letters.
  4. In the Admin, use email for username and email, enter full name, and the password in line from the login sheet. Change privilege level to None and Save.
  5. Add first and last name fields, save.
  6. Go to User Roles, add Health Insights User, save.
  7. Test login credentials before sending to user.

Rotating the tiles

The steps to rotate tiles on a landing page are simple.

  1. Open the landing page as a reference in one.
  2. Open the landing page in admin backend.
    • Options are Home, Key Topics, or Premium Content.
  3. Open a tab with data:text/html, <html contenteditable> to store text
  4. Starting with the tile where rotation starts, copy all field content over to the text storage tab. This includes Title, Link, and for public content, social links.

posts.html:
Project details

First, thank you for joining to assist on this project.
Manatt-mission-log.ghost.io is host to an internal blog for our healthcare consulting group. The primary functions required are best organized in three tracks.

  1. Projects – Individual authors make posts with status updates for projects they are working on. There will be a minimum of 1 post per Project, an overview page. Additional page components should be made available as templates to use in project updates. This work is primarily focused on Ghost posts and building best practices for our API and data structure. We need to associate multiple authors per project post.
  2. Social – Users create events on a displayed calendar via internal form. Those events can be added to Outlook calendar. This also includes the slack integration, configuring the author pages, and custom static pages like Seamless recommendations by city.
  3. Management – The backend work making Ghost meet organizational needs regarding Admin, Editor, and Author security. Hassle free log-in experience compliant with security. Ability to make content viewable to specific user lists. End all goal is secure connection to big data, encryption at post level.
    The below tasks are identified on the second left column as Required, Priority, or Accessory, in the middle a description, and on the right, likely category. There is a total of 15.

ID
Need
Name
Category

1
Required
Create Project Overview template post.
Project

2
Required
Duplicate posts and copy components like tables, charts, etc. into
new posts.
Project, Management

3
Required
Multiple authors to project post, and structure project post data to use
API and RSS.
Project, Management

4
Required
Calendar page updated with form input. Ability to add event through
UI.

Social

5
Priority
Modify author template to feature authors involvement in projects.
Social

6
Required
Configure user admin from list securely.

Management

7
Priority
Ability to create content visible by user lists.
Management

8
Priority
Add and track tasks/hours for a project on page. Ideally with Slack
integration.
Project

9
Accessory
Configure ‘City’ pages, with custom items like restaurant lists, and
comments.
Social

10
Priority
Data visualization and real time tabulation of project hours and
projected availability.
Social, Project

11
Accessory
Configure page level analytics for GA.
Management

12
Priority
Add multi-variable form, and securely transfer user form input to
database.
Management

13
Priority
Make ‘navigational’ pages like sitemap, Projects index, Author index,
and search.
Management

14
Accessory
PDF to tags page with Google’s NLP api.
Project, Management

15
Accessory
Customize user emails/alerts on backend.
Management.

Additional Guidance

Each category has a Manatt consultant available to answer questions and serve as a real user sounding board.

  • For projects – please reach out to Connor.
  • For Social – please reach out to Kyla.
  • For Management – Please reach out to Catherine.

Thomasina is leading user training, so Manatt team should summarize functionality to her as tasks are completed. We will work to create comprehensive documentation before launch, so all users have a smooth onboard.

Our success over three weeks long sprints is based on the final experience and usage of the project blog, not the amount of completed tasks. We should be feature testing all required functions by end of Week 2, giving time for feedback and edits Week 3.

We aim to increase internal knowledge about projects spanning offices across the country, and teams that never see each other. We also want to drive company culture and make it easier for people to know what is going on.

When looking to solve a problem, we prioritize:

  • Lightweight over robust
  • Secure/enterprise over open-source
  • Speed over style
  • User interaction over more navigation
  • Legacy support (IE) over mobile-first

We are looking to build off the default Casper theme, but would be open to recommendations for alt-themes. If there is a theme that would save you time getting these tasks up and started and lead to a better product, let me know and we will review and approve ASAP. Additionally, if there are graphics, images or design components you forecast needing, we can provide those as well.

I return to full development hours 4/9 and will be available for review and immediate feedback.
posts.plaintext:
Project details
First,  thank you for joining to assist on this project.
Manatt-mission-log.ghost.io is host to an internal blog for our healthcare
consulting group. The primary functions required are best organized in three
tracks.

 1. Projects  – Individual authors make posts with status updates for projects
    they are working on. There will be a minimum of 1 post per Project, an
    overview page. Additional page components should be made available as
    templates to use in project updates. This work is primarily focused on Ghost
    posts and building best practices for our API and data structure. We need to
    associate multiple authors per project post.
 2. Social  – Users create events on a displayed calendar via internal form.
    Those events can be added to Outlook calendar. This also includes the slack
    integration, configuring the author pages, and custom static pages like
    Seamless recommendations by city.
 3. Management  – The backend work making Ghost meet organizational needs
    regarding Admin, Editor, and Author security. Hassle free log-in experience
    compliant with security. Ability to make content viewable to specific user
    lists. End all goal is secure connection to big data, encryption at post
    level.
    The below tasks are identified on the second left column as Required,
    Priority, or Accessory, in the middle a description, and on the right,
    likely category. There is a total of 15.


ID

Need

Name

Category

1

Required

Create Project Overview template post.

Project

2

Required

Duplicate posts and copy components like tables, charts, etc. into
new posts.

Project, Management

3

Required

Multiple authors to project post, and structure project post data to use
API and RSS.

Project, Management

4

Required

Calendar page updated with form input. Ability to add event through
UI. 

Social

5

Priority

Modify author template to feature authors involvement in projects.

Social

6

Required

Configure user admin from list securely. 

Management

7

Priority

Ability to create content visible by user lists.

Management

8

Priority

Add and track tasks/hours for a project on page. Ideally with Slack
integration.

Project

9

Accessory

Configure ‘City’ pages, with custom items like restaurant lists, and
comments.

Social

10

Priority

Data visualization and real time tabulation of project hours and
projected availability.

Social, Project

11

Accessory

Configure page level analytics for GA.

Management

12

Priority

Add multi-variable form, and securely transfer user form input to
database.

Management

13

Priority

Make ‘navigational’ pages like sitemap, Projects index, Author index,
and search.

Management

14

Accessory

PDF to tags page with Google’s NLP api.

Project, Management

15

Accessory

Customize user emails/alerts on backend.

Management.
Additional Guidance
Each category has a Manatt consultant available to answer questions and serve as
a real user sounding board.

 * For projects – please reach out to Connor.
 * For Social – please reach out to Kyla.
 * For Management – Please reach out to Catherine.

Thomasina is leading user training, so Manatt team should summarize
functionality to her as tasks are completed. We will work to create
comprehensive documentation before launch, so all users have a smooth onboard.

Our success over three weeks long sprints is based on the final experience and
usage of the project blog, not the amount of completed tasks. We should be
feature testing all required functions by end of Week 2, giving time for
feedback and edits Week 3.

We aim to increase internal knowledge about projects spanning offices across the
country, and teams that never see each other. We also want to drive company
culture and make it easier for people to know what is going on.

When looking to solve a problem, we prioritize:

 * Lightweight over robust
 * Secure/enterprise over open-source
 * Speed over style
 * User interaction over more navigation
 * Legacy support (IE) over mobile-first

We are looking to build off the default Casper theme, but would be open to
recommendations for alt-themes. If there is a theme that would save you time
getting these tasks up and started and lead to a better product, let me know and
we will review and approve ASAP. Additionally, if there are graphics, images or
design components you forecast needing, we can provide those as well.

I return to full development hours 4/9 and will be available for review and
immediate feedback.

posts.title: Telemedicine strategy
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"## Telemedicine 50 state survey and related work ### Jared Augenstein, Jacqueline Marks

Medicaid Coverage and Reimbursement

Category Grade B
Is there state legislation regarding Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for services rendered via telemedicine? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse telemedicine services at the same rate as services delivered in-person? No
Medicaid-Eligible Patient Settings C
Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on patient setting (e.g., where the patient is located at the time of a telemedicine encounter)? Yes
Medicaid-Eligible Provider Types C
Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on the type of provider facilitating the telemedicine encounter? Yes
Medicaid-Eligible Technologies B
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via live video conference? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via store and forward technologies? No
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via remote patient monitoring? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via email/phone/fax? No
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for sychronous telemedicine encounters? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for asychronous telemedicine encounters? No
Medicaid Service Limitations B
Does the state Medicaid program apply any geographic restrictions to telemedicine encounters? No Reference Found
Does the state Medicaid program limit coverage and reimbursement for telemedicine to a prescribed set of health conditions or services? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program limit the frequency with which they will reimburse for telemedicine services for a given patient? No
Does the state Medicaid plan restrict or provide exceptions for services provided via telemedicine for end-stage renal disease or dialysis? (e.g., in-person check-ups between treatments) No
Corporate Practice of Medicine B
Does the state prohibit the corporate practice of medicine? Yes
Other (No Grade) A
Details on innovative payment and service delivery models or other state programs that include telehealth. The TX HHS code states: " The Health and Human Services Commission shall: (1) explore opportunities to increase STAR Health program providers' use of telemedicine medical services in medically underserved areas of this state; and (2) encourage STAR Health program providers to use telemedicine medical services as appropriate."

"Not later than December 1 of each even-numbered year, the commission shall report to the speaker of the house of representatives and the lieutenant governor on the effects of telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, and home telemonitoring services on Medicaid in the state, including the number of physicians, health professionals, and licensed health care facilities using telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, or home telemonitoring services, the geographic and demographic disposition of the physicians and health professionals, the number of patients receiving telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, and home telemonitoring services, the types of services being provided, and the cost of utilization of telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, and home telemonitoring services to Medicaid."
Relevant guidance related to telehealth or telemedicine within Medicaid Managed Care contracts from this state. Telemedicine, telehealth, and telemonitoring are Covered Services and are benefits of Texas Medicaid as provided in the Texas Medicaid Provider Procedures Manual. MCOs are encouraged to contract with Providers offering these services to provide better access to healthcare for its Members. In addition, a Medicaid MCO must be able to accept and process Provider claims for these services in conformity with the Texas Medicaid benefit.
"}]],"markups":[],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Telemedicine 50 state survey and related work

Jared Augenstein, Jacqueline Marks

Medicaid Coverage and Reimbursement

Category Grade B
Is there state legislation regarding Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for services rendered via telemedicine? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse telemedicine services at the same rate as services delivered in-person? No
Medicaid-Eligible Patient Settings C
Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on patient setting (e.g., where the patient is located at the time of a telemedicine encounter)? Yes
Medicaid-Eligible Provider Types C
Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on the type of provider facilitating the telemedicine encounter? Yes
Medicaid-Eligible Technologies B
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via live video conference? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via store and forward technologies? No
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via remote patient monitoring? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for telemedicine services provided via email/phone/fax? No
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for sychronous telemedicine encounters? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for asychronous telemedicine encounters? No
Medicaid Service Limitations B
Does the state Medicaid program apply any geographic restrictions to telemedicine encounters? No Reference Found
Does the state Medicaid program limit coverage and reimbursement for telemedicine to a prescribed set of health conditions or services? Yes
Does the state Medicaid program limit the frequency with which they will reimburse for telemedicine services for a given patient? No
Does the state Medicaid plan restrict or provide exceptions for services provided via telemedicine for end-stage renal disease or dialysis? (e.g., in-person check-ups between treatments) No
Corporate Practice of Medicine B
Does the state prohibit the corporate practice of medicine? Yes
Other (No Grade) A
Details on innovative payment and service delivery models or other state programs that include telehealth. The TX HHS code states: " The Health and Human Services Commission shall: (1) explore opportunities to increase STAR Health program providers' use of telemedicine medical services in medically underserved areas of this state; and (2) encourage STAR Health program providers to use telemedicine medical services as appropriate."

"Not later than December 1 of each even-numbered year, the commission shall report to the speaker of the house of representatives and the lieutenant governor on the effects of telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, and home telemonitoring services on Medicaid in the state, including the number of physicians, health professionals, and licensed health care facilities using telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, or home telemonitoring services, the geographic and demographic disposition of the physicians and health professionals, the number of patients receiving telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, and home telemonitoring services, the types of services being provided, and the cost of utilization of telemedicine medical services, telehealth services, and home telemonitoring services to Medicaid."
Relevant guidance related to telehealth or telemedicine within Medicaid Managed Care contracts from this state. Telemedicine, telehealth, and telemonitoring are Covered Services and are benefits of Texas Medicaid as provided in the Texas Medicaid Provider Procedures Manual. MCOs are encouraged to contract with Providers offering these services to provide better access to healthcare for its Members. In addition, a Medicaid MCO must be able to accept and process Provider claims for these services in conformity with the Texas Medicaid benefit.

posts.html:
This is a very simple Google Timeline chart.

Final Result

The only code added to the post body to create this Timeline is:

<div id="example3.1" style="width: 100%;"></div>

The original code provided by Google was very similar:

<div id="example3.1" style="height: 200px;"></div>

Add script in Header Injection

And in the Header, we add the details required for the chart. Here is the source for the example explaining all the options available using Google Charts API:

https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/gallery/timeline

Hopefully this gives you some ideas on how to leverage open source visualization/interactive libraries. You can access this post on the Backend here: https://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/ghost/#/editor/5ae3468d4bdd610022f55819
posts.plaintext:
This is a very simple Google Timeline chart. Final Result The only code added to the post body to create this Timeline is:
The original code provided by Google was very similar:
Add script in Header Injection And in the Header, we add the details required for the chart. Here is the source for the example explaining all the options available using Google Charts API: https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/gallery/timeline Hopefully this gives you some ideas on how to leverage open source visualization/interactive libraries. You can access this post on the Backend here: https://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/ghost/#/editor/5ae3468d4bdd610022f55819
posts.codeinjection_head:
<script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.gstatic.com/charts/loader.js"></script>

<script type="text/javascript">
  google.charts.load("current", {packages:["timeline"]});
  google.charts.setOnLoadCallback(drawChart);
  function drawChart() {

    var container = document.getElementById('example3.1');
    var chart = new google.visualization.Timeline(container);
    var dataTable = new google.visualization.DataTable();
    dataTable.addColumn({ type: 'string', id: 'Position' });
    dataTable.addColumn({ type: 'string', id: 'Name' });
    dataTable.addColumn({ type: 'date', id: 'Start' });
    dataTable.addColumn({ type: 'date', id: 'End' });
    dataTable.addRows([
      [ 'President', 'George Washington', new Date(1789, 3, 30), new Date(1797, 2, 4) ],
      [ 'President', 'John Adams', new Date(1797, 2, 4), new Date(1801, 2, 4) ],
      [ 'President', 'Thomas Jefferson', new Date(1801, 2, 4), new Date(1809, 2, 4) ],
      [ 'Vice President', 'John Adams', new Date(1789, 3, 21), new Date(1797, 2, 4)],
      [ 'Vice President', 'Thomas Jefferson', new Date(1797, 2, 4), new Date(1801, 2, 4)],
      [ 'Vice President', 'Aaron Burr', new Date(1801, 2, 4), new Date(1805, 2, 4)],
      [ 'Vice President', 'George Clinton', new Date(1805, 2, 4), new Date(1812, 3, 20)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'John Jay', new Date(1789, 8, 25), new Date(1790, 2, 22)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'Thomas Jefferson', new Date(1790, 2, 22), new Date(1793, 11, 31)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'Edmund Randolph', new Date(1794, 0, 2), new Date(1795, 7, 20)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'Timothy Pickering', new Date(1795, 7, 20), new Date(1800, 4, 12)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'Charles Lee', new Date(1800, 4, 13), new Date(1800, 5, 5)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'John Marshall', new Date(1800, 5, 13), new Date(1801, 2, 4)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'Levi Lincoln', new Date(1801, 2, 5), new Date(1801, 4, 1)],
      [ 'Secretary of State', 'James Madison', new Date(1801, 4, 2), new Date(1809, 2, 3)]
    ]);

    chart.draw(dataTable);
  }
</script>

{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"After completing this tutorial you will have successfully created a new client, assigned a project, and add two posts to the project. As a reminder, you can access the Admin panel here: https://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/ghost/

### Video tutorial

Follow along with the steps below. 

<iframe width="630" height="355" src="https://www.useloom.com/embed/e4e48b05ddc04fd39aa046d5b9d7e1a7" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

### Create your tags

1. Create a tag for the client. 
2. Edit tag meta name to `client`
3. Optionally, but helpfully, add an image and a description.
4. Create a tag for the project.
5. Edit tag meta name to `project`
6. Optionally, but helpfully, add an image and a description.

### Create your posts 
Around 1:10 minute mark

1. Navigate to Stories, and create New.
2. The page you are creating will be the Project Overview for your newly created project and client.
3. After entering some text to the post body, add tags in this order:
    1. `Projects`
    2. `Project Name`
    3. `Client Name`
4. Add the image any collaborators on the project as Authors.
5. Publish and check your work.
6. Create another new story, this one will be nested underneath the Project Overview you just made.
7. Add post title and body text.
8. Add `Project Name` tag to the post.

## THAT IS IT!

You can confirm your work by checking your author page. You should now the newly created Client, with a large Project Overview, and the nested update.

In order to successfully open this blog to the Health division by end of May, it would be extremely helpful if you could go through this tutorial and provide candid feedback by 5/11. We will have new features for review shortly, but making sure our posts are effectively organized is a top priority and we want to make sure the solution works for anticipated needs.

And **do not be shy** about making lots of posts, changing tags that are already created, and just trying out ideas. We will have a content review period to clean up before launch so if you try something that does not work we can always fix it.

### Bonus user testing

A great benefit of the internal blog will be putting faces to projects. You can edit your profile from the [Admin panel](https://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/ghost/). Just go to the top left menu, select Your Profile, and add a Bio, City, Image, and Cover photo. The info you populate there will complete your Author profile that appears on your page and posts you make."}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
After completing this tutorial you will have successfully created a new client, assigned a project, and add two posts to the project. As a reminder, you can access the Admin panel here: https://manatt-mission-log.ghost.io/ghost/

Video tutorial

Follow along with the steps below.

Create your tags

  1. Create a tag for the client.
  2. Edit tag meta name to client
  3. Optionally, but helpfully, add an image and a description.
  4. Create a tag for the project.
  5. Edit tag meta name to project
  6. Optionally, but helpfully, add an image and a description.

Create your posts

Around 1:10 minute mark

  1. Navigate to Stories, and create New.
  2. The page you are creating will be the Project Overview for your newly created project and client.
  3. After entering some text to the post body, add tags in this order:
    1. Projects
    2. Project Name
    3. Client Name
  4. Add the image any collaborators on the project as Authors.
  5. Publish and check your work.
  6. Create another new story, this one will be nested underneath the Project Overview you just made.
  7. Add post title and body text.
  8. Add Project Name tag to the post.

THAT IS IT!

You can confirm your work by checking your author page. You should now the newly created Client, with a large Project Overview, and the nested update.

In order to successfully open this blog to the Health division by end of May, it would be extremely helpful if you could go through this tutorial and provide candid feedback by 5/11. We will have new features for review shortly, but making sure our posts are effectively organized is a top priority and we want to make sure the solution works for anticipated needs.

And do not be shy about making lots of posts, changing tags that are already created, and just trying out ideas. We will have a content review period to clean up before launch so if you try something that does not work we can always fix it.

Bonus user testing

A great benefit of the internal blog will be putting faces to projects. You can edit your profile from the Admin panel. Just go to the top left menu, select Your Profile, and add a Bio, City, Image, and Cover photo. The info you populate there will complete your Author profile that appears on your page and posts you make.

posts.title: NY Professionals May Convener
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"## Patti Updates

### New Hampshire - 2 separate contracts, MMC and Expansion?
* Medicaid Expansion Workout
* Alice Lam on team
* Requires state to extend work requirements. 
* Opposition to expansion at state level, but governor is negotiating

Final approval of the bill through the legislature,
Second amendment waiver could be floated to the public.

In public comments for 30 days, will have to reply to comments in 2-3 weeks before submission. Really challenging, exciting work.

### RWJ Commonwealth on implementation of work requirements for states

Mindy Lipson, Allison Orriss

Trying to remain unbiased on the issue, but as we have dug into what States have experienced, we have the impression there are expensive implementation challenges that add complexity to work requirement implementation considerations.

### And a second grant. Data assets states should leverage and monitor the health impact of work requirements.

April Grady
This is a huge research opportunity

### University of Chicago Medicine
Eric, Chris Cantrell, Jared Augenstein
$70B in funding
Demographics include Medicare/Medicaid for population
Wrapping up an IT strategy
* Began in 2012, and hired again each year to update
* Workshops conducted on data science, and telemedicine?
* How to link discovery into the care model, accelerate using IT
* Community Health goals established
Launching a clinicial strategy
Question?
Tom Enders originally provided strategy consulting, opening the door for IT strategy consulting. Tom continues to handle projects for the dean, and that helped blossom into 
CIO from Chicago transferred to Stanford, and brought Manatt on for an IT strategy project at Stanford, including general IT strategy to Children's Hospital.

### North Carolina Managed Care program rollout
Kinda, Edith
This project was a huge deliverable of hundreds of pages of expertise. We are making 6 webinars out of this content. The first three come out this summer and the next three we will release in the fall. Subjects are:
1. Subject one
2. Subject two
3. Subject three
4. Subject four
5. Data trends and opioid 
6. Subject six
640+ webinar subscribers are already interested in this series. BNA will do a series of articles on the webinars as well.

### Alice updates on public policy advocacy strategy
There are advocacy areas close to heart for our clients that we help organize their policy arguments and legal analysis. Broad group of contributors across the table including consulting and legal members.

Pro-bono client comes to us with 10-12 projects to potentially tackle, and we will dive deep into at least one.

### Ian on Twitter. Pharmaceutical announcement from administration.

*Cynical reaction*
Our administration has checked out of health policy. Less tweets about HC policy, they are following a strategy of wait and let die for Obamacare, and is using the announcement to deliver on his campaign promises to lower drug policy.

When looking at the substance of the announcement, and the reaction of stocks, you will see there was a lot in the proposal that the 

*Non-cynical reaction*
The administration is serious about acting on addressing costs of healthcare for consumers. Could address policy in Medicare Part B/D and Medicaid.

Our life sciences and pharmaceutical clients are interested in understanding the substance of the content and we are working with Precision to get injected into the public domain. We have to be sensitive as to how we present our analysis in the national media, but it is worth exploring.

"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}

posts.title: Color scheme generator
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"You should consider all the viewing contexts when picking colors for maps, tables, and graphics for public or client work. While the design might look perfect on our monitors, it might be less clear if you printed it out in Greyscale or were colorblind.

### Color Safe - [http://colorsafe.co/](http://colorsafe.co/)

let's you choose a background color for placing fonts. 

### Color Brewer - [http://colorbrewer2.org](http://colorbrewer2.org)

makes the process painless to have great color schemes that work for anyone. Just input at the top # of data colors needed, pick your color scheme type, and make sure colorblind safe and print friendly are checked.

### TYPES OF COLOR SCHEMES

1. Sequential schemes are suited to ordered data that progress from low to high. Lightness steps dominate the look of these schemes, with light colors for low data values to dark colors for high data values. 
![sequential](/content/images/2018/05/sequential.png)
2. Diverging schemes put equal emphasis on mid-range critical values and extremes at both ends of the data range. The critical class or break in the middle of the legend is emphasized with light colors and low and high extremes are emphasized with dark colors that have contrasting hues.
![diverging](/content/images/2018/05/diverging.png)
3. Qualitative schemes do not imply magnitude differences between legend classes, and hues are used to create the primary visual differences between classes. Qualitative schemes are best suited to representing nominal or categorical data.
![qualitative](/content/images/2018/05/qualitative.png)
Further reading
[Brewer, Cynthia A. 1994. Color use guidelines for mapping and visualization. Chapter 7 (pp. 123-147) in Visualization in Modern Cartography](http://www.personal.psu.edu/faculty/c/a/cab38/ColorSch/SchHome.html)"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
You should consider all the viewing contexts when picking colors for maps, tables, and graphics for public or client work. While the design might look perfect on our monitors, it might be less clear if you printed it out in Greyscale or were colorblind.

Color Safe - http://colorsafe.co/

let's you choose a background color for placing fonts.

Color Brewer - http://colorbrewer2.org

makes the process painless to have great color schemes that work for anyone. Just input at the top # of data colors needed, pick your color scheme type, and make sure colorblind safe and print friendly are checked.

TYPES OF COLOR SCHEMES

  1. Sequential schemes are suited to ordered data that progress from low to high. Lightness steps dominate the look of these schemes, with light colors for low data values to dark colors for high data values.
  2. Diverging schemes put equal emphasis on mid-range critical values and extremes at both ends of the data range. The critical class or break in the middle of the legend is emphasized with light colors and low and high extremes are emphasized with dark colors that have contrasting hues.
  3. Qualitative schemes do not imply magnitude differences between legend classes, and hues are used to create the primary visual differences between classes. Qualitative schemes are best suited to representing nominal or categorical data.

    Further reading
    Brewer, Cynthia A. 1994. Color use guidelines for mapping and visualization. Chapter 7 (pp. 123-147) in Visualization in Modern Cartography
posts.plaintext:
You should consider all the viewing contexts when picking colors for maps,
tables, and graphics for public or client work. While the design might look
perfect on our monitors, it might be less clear if you printed it out in
Greyscale or were colorblind.

Color Safe - http://colorsafe.co/
let's you choose a background color for placing fonts.

Color Brewer - http://colorbrewer2.org
makes the process painless to have great color schemes that work for anyone.
Just input at the top # of data colors needed, pick your color scheme type, and
make sure colorblind safe and print friendly are checked.

TYPES OF COLOR SCHEMES
 1. Sequential schemes are suited to ordered data that progress from low to
    high. Lightness steps dominate the look of these schemes, with light colors
    for low data values to dark colors for high data values.
    
 2. Diverging schemes put equal emphasis on mid-range critical values and
    extremes at both ends of the data range. The critical class or break in the
    middle of the legend is emphasized with light colors and low and high
    extremes are emphasized with dark colors that have contrasting hues.
    
 3. Qualitative schemes do not imply magnitude differences between legend
    classes, and hues are used to create the primary visual differences between
    classes. Qualitative schemes are best suited to representing nominal or
    categorical data.
    
    Further reading
    Brewer, Cynthia A. 1994. Color use guidelines for mapping and
    visualization.
    Chapter 7 (pp. 123-147) in Visualization in Modern Cartography
    [http://www.personal.psu.edu/faculty/c/a/cab38/ColorSch/SchHome.html]

posts.title: Telehealth 50 State Alaska
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"

Alaska Telehealth Survey

Overall grade - Progressive 

Practice Standards and Licensure - Progressive
Medicaid-Eligible Provider Types - Progressive
Medicaid Coverage and Reimbursement - Progressive
Medicaid-Eligible Patient Settings - Progressive
Medicaid-Eligible Technologies - Progressive
Medicaid Service Limitations - Evolving
Corporate Practice of Medicine - No Grade
Practice Standards and Licensure
How does the state define telemedicine?
"Telemedicine" means the practice of health care delivery, evaluation, diagnosis, consultation, or treatment, using the transfer of medical data, audio, visual, or data communications that are performed over two or more locations between providers who are physically separated from the recipient or from each other.
# Questions Answer Clarifying Details Sources
1 How does the state define telemedicine? "Telemedicine" means the practice of health care delivery, evaluation, diagnosis, consultation, or treatment, using the transfer of medical data, audio, visual, or data communications that are performed over two or more locations between providers who are physically separated from the recipient or from each other.
2 Must a provider establish a relationship with a patient prior to engaging with them via telemedicine? No A physician is not required to carry out a physical exam prior to treating or diagnosing a patient if: (1) the physician or another provider is available to provide follow-up care; and (2) the physician follows guidelines for obtaining patient consent and sending copies of the patient's records to the person’s primary care provider.
3 Must a telepresenter or health care provider be present with a patient during a telemedicine encounter? No Reference Found No mention in state Medicaid policy.
4 Must providers obtain informed consent from a patient prior to a telemedicine encounter? No Reference Found No mention in state Medicaid policy.
5 If applicable, what type of consent is required? No Reference Found No mention in state Medicaid policy.
6 Can telemedicine providers from bordering states legally conduct telemedicine visits with patients in this state? Yes SB 74 expands the use of telehealth services and eliminates the requirement that providers rendering telemedicine services be located in Alaska.
"2016 Alaska Laws Ch. 25 (S.B. 74); Alaska Stat. Ann. § 08.64.101 "
7 Has this state enacted laws adopting the Federal State Medical Boards (FSMB) compact which enforces expedited licensing for out-of-state practices? No  
Interstate Medical Licensure Compact.
Medicaid Coverage and Reimbursement
# Questions Answer Clarifying Details Sources
1 Is there state legislation regarding Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services? Yes
2016 Alaska Laws Ch. 25 (S.B. 74); Alaska Stat. Ann. § 47.05.270
2 Does the state Medicaid program reimburse for services rendered via telemedicine? Yes
2016 Alaska Laws Ch. 25 (S.B. 74); Alaska Stat. Ann. § 47.05.270
3 Does the state Medicaid program reimburse telemedicine services at the same rate as services delivered in-person? No Reference Found
Medicaid-Eligible Patient Settings
# Questions Answer Clarifying Details Sources
1 Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on patient setting (e.g., where the patient is located at the time of a telemedicine encounter)? No
7 AAC 110.635
Medicaid-Eligible Provider Types
# Questions Answer Clarifying Details Sources
1 Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on the type of provider facilitating the telemedicine encounter? Yes Eligible providers include: - physician - podiatrist - chiropractor - physician assistant - nurse practitioner - licensed audiologist - speech-language pathologist - professional counselor - marriage and family therapist - psychologist - psychological associate - social worker - physical therapist - occupational therapist - registered speech-language - pathologist assistant 2016 Alaska Laws Ch. 25 (S.B. 74)
7 AAC 110.635

Alaska Telehealth Survey

Overall grade - Progressive 

Practice Standards and Licensure - Progressive
Medicaid-Eligible Provider Types - Progressive
Medicaid Coverage and Reimbursement - Progressive
Medicaid-Eligible Patient Settings - Progressive
Medicaid-Eligible Technologies - Progressive
Medicaid Service Limitations - Evolving
Corporate Practice of Medicine - No Grade
Practice Standards and Licensure
How does the state define telemedicine?
"Telemedicine" means the practice of health care delivery, evaluation, diagnosis, consultation, or treatment, using the transfer of medical data, audio, visual, or data communications that are performed over two or more locations between providers who are physically separated from the recipient or from each other.
# Questions Answer Clarifying Details Sources
1 How does the state define telemedicine? "Telemedicine" means the practice of health care delivery, evaluation, diagnosis, consultation, or treatment, using the transfer of medical data, audio, visual, or data communications that are performed over two or more locations between providers who are physically separated from the recipient or from each other.
2 Must a provider establish a relationship with a patient prior to engaging with them via telemedicine? No A physician is not required to carry out a physical exam prior to treating or diagnosing a patient if: (1) the physician or another provider is available to provide follow-up care; and (2) the physician follows guidelines for obtaining patient consent and sending copies of the patient's records to the person’s primary care provider.
3 Must a telepresenter or health care provider be present with a patient during a telemedicine encounter? No Reference Found No mention in state Medicaid policy.
4 Must providers obtain informed consent from a patient prior to a telemedicine encounter? No Reference Found No mention in state Medicaid policy.
5 If applicable, what type of consent is required? No Reference Found No mention in state Medicaid policy.
6 Can telemedicine providers from bordering states legally conduct telemedicine visits with patients in this state? Yes SB 74 expands the use of telehealth services and eliminates the requirement that providers rendering telemedicine services be located in Alaska.
"2016 Alaska Laws Ch. 25 (S.B. 74); Alaska Stat. Ann. § 08.64.101 "
7 Has this state enacted laws adopting the Federal State Medical Boards (FSMB) compact which enforces expedited licensing for out-of-state practices? No  
Interstate Medical Licensure Compact.

1 Does the state limit Medicaid reimbursement for telemedicine services based on patient setting (e.g., where the patient is located at the time of a telemedicine encounter)? No
7 AAC 110.635
Medicaid-Eligible Provider Types
# Questions Answer Clarifying Details Sources

posts.html:
Application Training Tip of the Week: “How do I use Bcc to send emails via BLIND COPY?”

Monte Lemann’s recent email reminds us to blind copy all recipients on a bulk email, rather than putting their email in the To: or Cc: fields.
Using Bcc: or Blind carbon copy prevents the recipients from inadvertently using Reply to All.

Monte Lemann’s recent email reminds us to blind copy all recipients on a bulk email, rather than putting their email in the To: or Cc: fields.
Using Bcc: or Blind carbon copy prevents the recipients from inadvertently using Reply to All.

To find the Bcc: field –

  1. Open a new e-mail message, and then click Options.
  2. On the Options tab, in the Show Fields area, click Bcc.
  3. Close the new email without saving.
